awd_titl_txt: SBIR Phase I:  Caged Urea as an Eco-friendly Nitrogen Fertilizer
awd_abstract_narration:
The broader/commercial impact of this Small Business Innovation Research (SBIR) Phase I project is the reduction in greenhouse gas emissions and water contamination due to nitrogen fertilizers. The project will also increase agricultural productivity at lower nitrogen application rates using a novel concept of urea trapped in molecular cages. Nitrogen fertilizers can be serious environmental pollutants. Available alternatives are either too expensive for general agricultural use or cause unwanted residue buildup and are, therefore, minimally used. Pollution from nitrogen fertilizers remains a serious concern globally. This project's impact is directed at three targets: (a) Farmer income: the proposed nitrogen fertilizer may increase crop yields by 5-10%, improve farm profits, and improve the income of 10% of the US population; (b) US economy: the technology may boost the US economy by global export of this fertilizer; and (c) Environment and health: the solution may reduce greenhouse gas emissions and water pollution from nitrogen fertilizer.  

The project is aimed at the development of a novel fertilizer compound, where urea is trapped within a biodegradable molecular cage. The molecular cage is designed to bind urea within its structure to reduce its solubility and reduce pollutant production. Nitrogen is released from this cage only when the cage is dissolved by root secretions (such as organic acids). This technology is an intelligent release mechanism where an insoluble nutrient is released only on demand by the plant. The cage itself is constructed of plant nutrients therefore, when the plant dissolves the cage, it not only gets its nitrogen from urea but also consumes the cage because the cage is also food to the plant. To have a commercially successful product, the team will optimize the performance of the caged urea to meet agronomic and environmental targets and farmer acceptability. These goals will be accomplished by modulating the cage-link bridges to improve the trapping of urea, reducing volatilization by controlling the microenvironment modifiers, controlling emissions during production, and improving the physical properties for ease-of-farmer use. This project will help to develop caged- urea into an environmentally impactful, agronomically beneficial, marketable, consumer friendly, and manufacturable commodity.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Technology, Innovation, and Partnerships

por.por_cntn:
Caged Urea as an Eco-friendly Nitrogen Fertilizer

Chandrika Varadachari, Agtec Innovations Inc

Nitrogen fertilizers such as urea are essential for all crops across the globe and make up the largest portion of the fertilizers used by farmers. However, the use of these conventional nitrogen fertilizers has significant environmental impacts. Nitrogen fertilizers contribute to environmental pollution by leaching into water bodies as toxic nitrate and volatilization as oxides of nitrogen contributing to global warming. Most recent solutions focus on (a) coating urea with polymers (plastics) to reduce their solubility and (b) on chemicals that deactivate the enzymes or organisms that are responsible for such transformations. However, cost factors, soil buildup of non-biodegradable materials, plastic accumulation in soils and lack of performance benefits have limited the usage of existing products.

To overcome these challenges and provide farmers with an environment-friendly alternative, Agtec Innovations Inc developed a ground-breaking new fertilizer called “caged-urea”.  This is a unique molecular structure where urea is trapped within a biodegradable inorganic “cage” consisting of interlinking phosphorus and calcium; both phosphorus and calcium are plant nutrients and hence beneficial additives. The structural framework itself is water insoluble but soluble by root activity. Urea thereby becomes part of the supramolecular structure, and this ensures some degree of protection from microbial enzymes thereby reducing nitrogen emissions and nitrate production. It leaves no toxic residues or microplastics because all chemical constituents are plant food.

The major goal of this NSF-SBIR Phase I project was to develop our innovation into a market acceptable fertilizer formulation by meeting several challenging criteria of improving critical performance parameters. We anticipated that that by reducing water solubility, significantly lowering ammonia emissions and nitrate production, making the production process more scalable and producing farmer-acceptable formulations, we would have a formulation that would be more environment-friendly, cost effective and provide the consumer with an alternative for higher profit margins.

With this project we succeeded in all our objectives. By modifying the structural features of the molecular cage and improving the trapping of urea within it, using cross-linking agents, we could achieve our targeted goals for an optimized product.  For this we have used the simplest of raw materials that consist entirely of plant nutrients that leave no residues in the soil. We also optimized the production process parameters to reduce energy requirements and emissions. 

We could develop formulations that showed 80-90% reduction in ammonia volatilization from soils. Our formulations also performed exceptionally in reducing nitrates in comparison to urea. The reductions in nitrate were around 40-50% and sometimes even over 70%. In some instances, they even performed better than competitor products which contain chemical inhibitors. Emission of N2O (nitrous oxide, a greenhouse gas) was reduced by over 60% compared to that with urea. Therefore, in terms of environmental impact, caged-urea could achieve significant improvements which can translate to improved water quality by reducing nitrates and reducing greenhouse gas emissions.

Cabbage trials with caged-urea showed 15% higher yield compared to urea and an overall increase in plant health. Tomato trials showed caged-urea performed better than urea and a competitor product at low N dose with increase in fruit count, biomass, %N recovery. Pepper produced 8.2% higher yields with caged-urea at 20% reduced nitrogen dosage compared to urea. Corn trials with various formulations produced over 20% yield increases at 40% reduced dosages compared to urea. In all trials, caged urea was applied as single dose whereas urea was applied in 2-4 split applications.

We also expect that the crop response would be higher in poor soils with lower organic matter and in loose textured soils with higher N leaching. In terms of benefit to the farmers this would have greater impact. Since caged-urea requires only a single application compared to multiple applications for urea, there would be a significant saving in labor and time for the farmer. Higher yields would provide further inducement to farmers for using caged-urea as a nitrogen fertilizer.

This scientific impact of this project is the development of a biodegradable molecular cage that can be used to reduce environmental pollution and improve efficiency for nitrogen fertilization. It will transform the current approach to reducing fertilizer leaching using encapsulation, that is both expensive and adds unwanted materials to the soil.

Our innovation has the potential to significantly enhance the U.S. economy by driving improved agricultural productivity. Increasing agricultural output, could generate billions of dollars in revenue, elevate incomes across the population through greater food availability, and strengthen export opportunities for both agricultural commodities and our caged-urea product.

Additionally, our solution will contribute to better air and water quality, fostering long-term health benefits for the population. On a broader scale, this innovation addresses critical global challenges, including the climate crisis, food security, and public health, ensuring a profound and lasting impact on both domestic and international levels.


Last Modified: 01/05/2025
Modified by: Chandrika Varadachari
